awd_titl_txt: TRIPODS+X:RES:Collaborative Research: Multi-Level Graph Representation for Exploring Big Data
awd_abstract_narration:
Working with social, topical, financial, transportation, biological, and other networks requires a better understanding of their structure and properties. Standard network visualizations of such large real-world networks often resemble hairballs that provide little actionable insight. This project aims to design, implement, and deploy efficient algorithms for multi-level network representations that support interactive exploration by general audiences. Using the familiar Google map metaphor, these algorithms will make it easy to identify important nodes, major pathways, and clusters across multiple levels. Unlike existing methods for visualizing multi-level networks based on meta-nodes and meta-edges, the new visualizations will provide real nodes (prototypes) and real paths (backbones) for each level, similar to geographic maps that show real cities and real roads at every level of detail.

The proposed work contributes to graph algorithms by designing and implementing novel and efficient algorithms for interactive analysis and visualization of large, multi-level networks, information visualization with new methods for multi-level network visualization based on the familiar map metaphor, and science mapping standards by providing effective means to explore and use large-scale, multi-level science maps of our collective scholarly knowledge as well as workforce needs. The first goal is to design efficient algorithms for computing Multi-Level Graph Spanners (MLGS) in support of visual analytics tasks for large network exploration, navigation, and communication. The second goal is to utilize the MLGS representation in the context of network analysis and visualization by building a novel online visualization service for interacting with large networks, which combines the MLGS approach with clustering, layout and map-like visualization. The third goal is to develop a new approach for science and workforce classification, lookup, and topical mapping service by applying the MLGS approach to the Web of Science publication data (64 million publications and 1 billion citations) to compute a multi-level map of scientific development. The fourth goal is to validate the new algorithms and visualizations by evaluating both the algorithms and the system using quantitative and qualitative metrics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: IU, School of Informatics, Computing, and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Working with social, topical, financial, transportation, biological, and other networks requires a better understanding of their structure and properties. Real-world networks are often large (i.e., millions of nodes and billions of edges) and hard to represent. Using standard network visualizations methods often generates layouts that look like “hairballs” and are difficult to read and interpret by users.

This project designed, implemented, and deployed efficient Multi-Level Graph Spanners (MLGS) algorithms that generate network visualizations that support user exploration using map-like layouts and interactions. This MLGS approach provides real nodes (prototypes) and real paths (backbones) for each level of a network, much like geographic maps that show real cities and real roads across various levels of prominence. The resulting networks support visual analytics tasks for large network exploration, navigation, and communication by making it easy to identify important nodes, major pathways, and clusters across multiple levels of abstraction.

The project has achieved four goals:

(1) Designed and implemented a multi-level tree-based approach for interactive graph visualization with semantic zoom, also known as ZMLT (see: https://github.com/cns-iu/map4sci). The ZMLT algorithm provides an efficient and interactive way to visualize large network graphs by using a multi-level tree-based approach. This approach is particularly useful for graphs with complex structures, where traditional force-directed layout algorithms may not produce the desired results. The implementation of the ZMLT algorithm incorporates three algorithms: Batch Tree (BatchTree), Compactness Guided (CG), and Deep Local and Global Features (DELG) that generate different layouts for input graphs.

(2) Used the MLGS algorithms in the context of network analysis and visualization by building a novel online visualization service for interacting with large networks, which combines the MLGS approach with clustering, layout, and map-like visualizations. The Map4Sci online visualization service developed under this grant has been used across multiple NSF and NIH funded projects, including SPOKE (https://cns-iu.github.io/spoke-vis), MyAURA (https://cns-iu.github.io/myaura), and HuBMAP (https://humanatlas.io).

(3) Applied the ZMLT service to PubMed MEDLINE publication data (includes data from 8,801,090 articles, 5,968 journals, and 29,818 MeSH descriptors) to compute a multi-level networks and maps of biomedical scientific development for the period (2013-2022), called the Open Biomedical Map of Science (https://cns-iu.github.io/obms). 

(4) Validate the new algorithms and visualizations: the Map4Sci service incorporates quality assurance and quality control metrics that support the evaluation of both the ZMLT algorithms and the system, including efficiency/scalability, stress/distortion and precision/recall. 


Last Modified: 01/17/2024
Modified by: Katy Borner
